can machines think, is just hopelessly

19.text:
when can a machine be mistaken for a real

So, Turing proposed the following thought
experiment.

26.text:
He says, imagine that you're in a room and
you're facing a barrier and behind the

31.text:
barrier, there's a human and there's a

34.text:
And you can ask these, the human and the

38.text:

50.text:

54.text:
about anything.

57.text:
place to buy wallpaper?
How do you feel about the current

62.text:
Whatever.

And Turing says, when we get to the point
that we cannot decide which is the human

70.text:
or which is the machine, or if our

75.text:
arbitrary, they we have managed to build a

machine, that's reached the appropriate

So, you have this human society and then,

So, he applies something like the Turing

He asks the machines and the humans lots

whether what he's talking to is a
replicate, a robot that's pretending to be

So, how good is the Turing test for

Here, there's some problems that

134.text:

First of all, it's language based, so all

138.text:
the testing is for an intelligence that
can communicate via language.

143.text:
We couldn't, for instance, check for
animal intelligence if those animals

147.text:
couldn't speak languages.
The second problem with the Turing test

151.text:
that people have raised, is that perhaps
it's too anthropocentric.

155.text:
Because what we're testing it for, is
whether a machine can be mistaken for

159.text:

Well, that means we're testing for human

162.text:

There could be lots of different forms of
intelligence out there which could be

174.text:
realized by a machine but which we're not
allowing an opportunity to shine through

180.text:
using the Turing Test.
The third problem with the Turing Test is

184.text:
that it doesn't take into account the
inner states of the machine.

188.text:
So, take, for example a machine that's
doing a sum.

192.text:
And you asked it, what's 2 plus 8?
Now, you could have a machine that does

197.text:
some sort of calculation, it thinks 2 plus
8, adds the two things together and gives

202.text:

But you could have a machine that's

206.text:
programmed in a certain way that when it
receives the input, 2 plus 8, it rattles

211.text:
through its files, and comes to a file
which says 2 plus 8 on it.

215.text:
Pulls it out, opens it up and it says, 10.
And it throws out the answer, 10.

219.text:
Now, in the first instance, we want to say
that, that machine is doing some kind of

223.text:
computation and it's going through some
kind of process, thought process.

227.text:
Whereas, the second machine is just
retrieving a file.

232.text:
Now, if it were possible to build a
machine that could pass Turing's test just

237.text:
using a file system, then surely this is a
bit worrying, because we don't, we don't

242.text:
seem to have thought processes.
We just have a machine that can retrieve

246.text:
lots of different files, and spit out the
answers.

249.text:
Now, this isn't necessarily a killer flaw
to Turing's plan.

252.text:
First of all, you could argue that a
machine that just pulls out files

256.text:
according to the questions which it was

261.text:
the test.
It would have to have such a gigantic file

264.text:
store and such a huge database searching
system, that is just wouldn't be the type

269.text:
of thing that could pass the test.
Secondly, any kind of machine that could

want to go all the way and say that it has

mentality, that it can have thought

But maybe what we should instead say, is

Turing test, then it must be worthwhile

What kind of thing could pass the Turing

The philosopher, John Searle, had some

317.text:
very interesting things to say about this.
He introduced us the following thought

322.text:
experiment.
He says, imagine that you are in a room

326.text:
and there are two slots entering the room.
One that says, I, and one that says, O.

331.text:
And what happens is you get symbols on
bits of paper that come through the eye

335.text:
slot.
Now, in your room, you have a book and in

338.text:
the book, it's a list of algorithms about
what to do depending on the type of symbol

343.text:
you receive.
So, if you receive a symbol, it might say,

347.text:
if you receive a symbol of type A, put out
a symbol of type B.

351.text:
So, you have a steady stream of symbols
coming in, and you look up in your book,

355.text:
what you should be putting out again, and
let's imagine that you just have a whole

360.text:
stack of these, these symbols available to
you in the room.

363.text:
So, you receive a symbol, you check in
your book what you should put through the

367.text:
output box, the O box, you pick up a
symbol, and put it back through the O box.

372.text:
Now imagine that, unknown to you, these
symbols are actually Chinese.

376.text:
And the person who is feeding in the
symbols is a Chinese speaker who is asking

381.text:
you questions.
So, what's happening is that you're

384.text:
receiving questions and you're actually
giving out answers.

387.text:
And the rule book is such that you're
actually giving our really quite coherent

392.text:
answers.
In fact, you're realizing something like a

395.text:
machine that would pass Turing's test.
So, the Chinese speaker outside really

400.text:
believes that she's conversing with
another Chinese speaker.

405.text:
Now, the big question that Searle asks is,
well, I, the person inside the box, or the

411.text:
person inside the room don't understand
Chinese.

415.text:
So, if I were unable to converse with this
Chinese speaker in a way that seems

420.text:
perfectly coherent to the person outside,
I, myself, have no understanding of what

425.text:
I'm doing.
It doesn't make sense to say, I understand

429.text:
Chinese, because I don't.
All I'm doing is looking up rules in this

433.text:
logbook.
And Searle points out that this is just

436.text:
how computers work.
Computers receive inputs and then their

440.text:
program is like the logbook.
The program tells them what sort of output

444.text:
they should give.
So, they check it, they check up or they

447.text:
run through a list of rules.
And see that, given a particular input,

451.text:
they should give a particular output.
But Searle's point is that, that machine

456.text:
can never itself be said to understand
Chinese.

460.text:
That machine isn't thinking, that machine
is just putting on a very good simulation

465.text:
of a thinker.
A simulation that's so good that it could

469.text:
fool, fool someone on the outside.
But a simulation that can't possibly count

474.text:
as thinking itself, because there is no
understanding involved.

478.text:
And this is one of the most important
questions that has been leveled at the

483.text:
computational matter of the mind.
We're saying minds are like computers,

487.text:
that minds take inputs, manipulate the,
and send out outputs.

491.text:
Then where does the meaning come in?
This turns back to one of our opening

495.text:
questions, the aboutness of thoughts.
We want to say that our thoughts are about

500.text:
things, that our thoughts have meaning,
that we can think about things, and yet,

505.text:
what we have on this computational view of
the mind is a system that has no

509.text:
understanding at all.
There's no meaning involved.

513.text:
The system just receives inputs and sends
out outputs.

517.text:
At no point do we have any understanding.
What's made it really salient by Searle's

522.text:
thought experiment is that computers only
work on syntactic properties of symbols.

528.text:
What does this mean?
Well, imagine you have a square with a

532.text:
line through it.
And that's a symbol.

535.text:
And let's just say that, that symbol is
Chinese for the question, do you like

539.text:
ducks?
And you're the person inside the Chinese

542.text:
room and you get the symbol in.
Now, all you have to work on is the

547.text:
syntactic properties of the symbols.
The syntactic property is just the square

552.text:
with the line, it's the shape of the
symbol if you like.

556.text:
So, you look at the shape of symbol and
you can add an answer depending on what

561.text:
the shape of the symbol is.
Now, the important thing about computers

565.text:
is that all they ever operate on are the
shapes of symbols.

569.text:
Computers don't need to understand what
those symbols stand for.

573.text:
The computer doesn't need to understand
that a square with a line through it means

577.text:
the question, do you like ducks, all it
needs to be able to do is run its program

582.text:
so that it knows what the correct output

585.text:
But this is misleading because what's very
important for human thought are the

591.text:
semantic properties.
Semantic properties are what that symbol

595.text:
stands for.
So, the square with a line through it

598.text:
stands for the question, do you like
ducks?

601.text:
What it stands for, the meaning is known
as the semantic property of that symbol.

606.text:
As humans, we can look at that symbol and
provided we understand the code, we know

610.text:
that it stands for the question, do you
like ducks?

613.text:
But computer doesn't need to know that.
The computer just needs to know how it

618.text:
ought to change that symbol and give a
particular output.

621.text:
This is Searle's point.
He says, that a system, no matter how

625.text:
functionally complex it is, even if they
can pass something like the Turing test

630.text:
that only other works on the syntactic
properties, the symbols, the shapes that

636.text:
they get, will never be a proper thinking
system because it will never have the

641.text:
aboutness.
It will never be able to understand the

644.text:
semantic value of those symbols.
And intuitively, in order to have a

649.text:
thinking system, you have to have a system
that understands the semantic properties

655.text:
of symbols as well as the syntactic ones.
